newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds end weaker with U.S., eye on jobs data.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds end weaker with U.S., eye on jobs data.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed slightly weaker on Wednesday, moving in tandem with a softer U.S. market, as anxious investors awaited the release of a key U.S. employment report on Friday, analysts said.

"We're definitely looking ahead to this big number on Friday. Markets are nervous and volumes aren't huge here. The flows are light today," said Hank Cunningham, a bond trader with First Marathon Securities.
Canada's 8.0 percent bond due 2023 fell C$0.25 to C$100.55 to yield 7.948 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark fell 13/32 to yield 7.09 percent.
Canadian economic data released today showing the value of Canadian building permits issued in July rose 7.1 percent had little impact on the market, analysts said.
In auction news, the Government of Canada auction today of C$3.0 billion of 6.25 percent bonds due September 15, 1998 had an average yield of 5.606 percent at an average price of C$101.210.
The two-year auction was the last scheduled for the third quarter of 1996 and the auction schedule for the fourth quarter is expected sometime within the next week, analysts said.
